data.title: Highly Composite Numbers
data.solution:
from itertools import accumulate

N = int(input())

def count_factors(n):
	cnt = 0
	for k in range(1,n+1):
		if n%k == 0:
			cnt += 1
	return cnt

def test_count_factors():
	assert count_factors(1) == 1
	assert count_factors(2) == 2
	assert count_factors(3) == 2
	assert count_factors(6) == 4
	assert count_factors(12) == 6
	assert count_factors(360) == 24

def get_factors_until(n):
	return [count_factors(k) for k in range(1,n+1)]

def test_get_factors_until():
	assert get_factors_until(6) == [1,2,2,3,2,4]

test_count_factors()
test_get_factors_until()

counts = get_factors_until(N)
running_max = [-1]+list(accumulate(counts, max))

ans = 0
for current_count, previous_max in zip(counts, running_max):
	if current_count > previous_max:
		ans += 1

print(ans)
data.statement:
Find the number of <<highly composite numbers>> less than or equal to [[N]].

A highly composite number (sometimes called an anti-prime) is a <<positive integer>> [[A]] with more divisors than any positive integer smaller than [[A]].

Note: 1 and 2 are considered highly composite numbers

See: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Highly_composite_number
data.outputDescription: A single integer representing the number of highly composite numbers less than or equal to [[N]]

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

Find the number of highly composite numbers less than or equal to N.

A highly composite number (sometimes called an anti-prime) is a positive integer A with more divisors than any positive integer smaller than A.

Note: 1 and 2 are considered highly composite numbers

See: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Highly_composite_number
Input
An integer N: the upper bound. (inclusive)
Output
A single integer representing the number of highly composite numbers less than or equal to N
Constraints
1 ≤ N ≤ 1000
Example
Input
1
Output
1
